summary: glial activation promotes the release of potentially toxic acute phase reactants such as TNF and nitric oxide into the extracellular space. the effects of virus-induced glial activation on oligodendrocytes are not fully understood. microglia and astrocytes have been shown to possess immune surveillance properties. the central nervous system is considered immune privileged, but is not without a functional defense system. however, both resident microglia and astrocytes have been shown to possess immune surveillance properties. idylic acid (poly(I:C)) causes release of soluble molecules with neuroprotective properties. over-activation of TLRs in absence of immunoregulation may be detrimental to the surrounding tissue. viral infections or aberrant inflammation are known to contribute to both animal and human demyelinating diseases. direct viral infection of glial cultures provides a relevant tool to model CNS viral-induced pathogenesis and/or tropism. however, infection of CNS-derived cultures with live virus often makes it difficult to separate virus-induced cytopathic effect (i.e. cell lysis) from bystander effects of activated glia. all experimental procedures were approved by the Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee. cells were washed twice with DMEM containing 10% heat-inactivated fetal bovine serum and 1% penicillin-streptomycin. microglia were isolated by shaking the mixed glia-containing flasks for 1 h. single cell suspensions from rat spleens were used as a positive control. cells were pelleted by centrifugation at 1500 g for 5 min. red blood cells were lysed with ammonium chloride (0.01 M) in PBS for 3 min at 24°C.
